publicationStmt.publisher: Pinakes Project - Institut de Recherche et d'Histoire des Textes (IRHT)

licence.p: Freely available for academic use. Digitized version available through the Vatican Library Digital Collections.

availability.p: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

msIdentifier.institution: Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana Vatican Vatican City

msItem.title: Catena Patrum Graecorum in Prophetas (Patristic Commentaries on Prophets)

layout.p: Text in one column per page with approximately 29 lines per page.

handNote.p: Majuscule script (Coptic Majuscule), primarily from a single scribe with contributions by different hands in the scholia.

decoDesc.decoNote: Contains marginal notes and symbols indicating lectionary divisions, cross-references, and patristic scholia.

provenance.p: The codex likely did not come to Europe before the 9th century. It arrived in Lower Italy before the 12th century, then moved to the Abbey of S. Denis in Paris, France. It was owned by René Marchal in the second half of the 16th century and Cardinal F. Rochefoucaud in 1636, who donated it to the Jesuit College of Clermont in Paris. The manuscript came to the Vatican in 1785.
Owners: René Marchal, Cardinal F. Rochefoucaud.

div.p: The following study presents a transcription and translation of pages 761-768 from the Codex Marchalianus (Vat. gr. 2125), a 6th-century parchment manuscript of the Prophetic books. Although the text is titled after Susanna, a righteous Jewish woman in Babylon, she plays a surprisingly passive role in the narrative. When two corrupt elders attempt to blackmail Susanna for sexual favors and then falsely accuse her of adultery, she faces a death sentence, with notably silent family members, including her husband, present at her trial. The climax of the story does not revolve around Susanna herself but rather the seemingly simplistic intervention of young Daniel. His well-known "interrogation" consists of asking each elder separately about the type of tree under which the alleged affair took place. Their contradicting answers are deemed sufficient proof of their dishonesty. Nevertheless, one might wonder why this single inconsistency was regarded as conclusive proof of their guilt, considering that not everyone can identify tree species from memory. Despite its title, the story focuses more on the elders' corruption and Daniel's dubious solution than on Susanna herself, who remains largely a plot device rather than a fully developed character.

The textual variants found in these passages of the Susanna narrative represent primarily minor differences that do not substantially alter the meaning of the text. The majority of variations fall into conventional categories of manuscript transmission: orthographic differences (such as the alternate spellings of ἴδες/εἶδες), grammatical alternations between singular and plural forms (as in εἶπεν/εἶπαν), simple word order changes (like the reversal of κορασίων μόνων to μόνων κορασίων), and case variations (such as τοῦ λαοῦ versus τῷ λαῷ). While there are some vocabulary variations, such as the alternation between ἀναγγέλλω and ἀπαγγέλλω (both meaning "to announce" or "report"), or between πρεσβυτερῖον and πρεσβεῖον (variant forms referring to eldership), these maintain essentially equivalent meanings. Only a few variants might be considered more substantive, such as the choice between μένει ("remains") and ἤδη ("now/already"), or the different expressions for false witnesses (ψευδομαρτυρήσαντας versus ψευδομάρτυρας ὄντας), but even these alternatives do not significantly impact the narrative's meaning or theological implications.

Spelling standardization and punctuation adjustments have been implemented within 'choice' elements, utilizing 'reg' and 'orig' tags to distinguish between the original and regularized forms. Textual variants are documented using 'app' with 'lem' and 'rdg' elements to facilitate comparisons with other manuscript witnesses. Morphological tags have been incorporated into the normalized text to identify lexical forms and grammatical features, employing '@lemma' and '@msd' attributes in 'w' elements.
div.note: The original instructions called for encoding variants using "choice" elements containing "lem" and "rdg" elements, but this structure produced validation errors. Instead, the encoding was successfully implemented using "app" elements with "lem" and "rdg" elements to document textual variants and facilitate manuscript witness comparisons. Spelling standardization and punctuation adjustments are still marked, but through this modified structure. The encoding retains full morphological tagging within the normalized text to identify lexical forms and grammatical features, employing lemma and morphological description attributes in word elements. This adaptation maintains the scholarly integrity of the encoding while avoiding technical validation issues that arose from the originally prescribed "choice" element structure.

div.ab: And there was a man living in Babylon and his name was Jehoiakim.
div.note: The present active nominative third person singular masculine οἰκῶν is used along with ἦν the imperfect active indicative third person singular of εἰμί, meaning 'was dwelling/living' depicting Jehoiakim's residence in Babylon as an established, ongoing situation in the past. The imperfect ἦν indicates the past: not a closed past but an ongoing one, and the participle is present but ongoing, so the two together show the ongoing nature of the dwelling.
div.ab: And he took a wife whose name was Susanna, daughter of Hilkiah, who was very beautiful and fearing the Lord.
div.note: The ommission of the verb "to be" εἰμί (was Susanna...who was very beautiful) is called an implied copula or ellipsis of the copula. This also occurs in Old Irish.
div.ab: And her parents were righteous, and they taught their daughter according to the law of Moses.
And Jehoiakim was very rich, and he had a garden adjacent (neighboring) to his house, and the Jews would gather to him because he was held in more esteem (honor) than all.
And two elders from the people were appointed judges in that year about whom the master spoke that lawlessness came out from Babylon from elder judges who appeared to govern (steer) the people.
div.note: The repeated use of ἐκ in ἐκ βαβυλῶνος and ἐκ πρεσβυτέρων κριτῶν emphasizes the specific source of lawlessness.
div.ab: These used to persist in the home of Jehoiakim and all those being judged used to come to them.
div.note: The plural substantival participle οἱ κρινόμενοι is used to transform the participle into a noun-ish expression.κρινόμενος, present middle/passive participle = being judged thus οἱ κρινόμενοι= those being judged.(see Basics of Biblical Greek, William D. Mounce, 273.)
div.ab: And it happened when the people were departing at midday, Susanna used to enter and would walk around in her husband's garden.
And the two elders kept watching her entering and walking around according to the day and they came to be in desire of (in lust for) her.
And they distorted their own mind
and they turned away their eyes so as not to look to the heaven, nor to remember righteous judgments.
div.note: This is interesting because the elders first decisively (thus aorist rather than imperfect/ongoing or habitual) διέστρεψαν that is, distorted their mind, making a mental decision, then ξέκλιναν physically turned aside their eyes. Both verbs involve a turning or twisting, one mental and the other physical. And expressed in the aorist tense, I think this is where they both decided to just give in and go for it.
div.ab: And they were both striken with about her, and they did not tell their pain to one another.
div.note: To reflect the passive voice of the perfect passive participle κατανενυγμένοι 'having been pierced/striken' but the perfect tense κατανενυγμένοι indicates a completed action with ongoing effects, so 'they had been striken and remained so' because it was an ongoing condition rather than a fleeting feeling they were experiencing.See Athenaze Book II,27a, page 185.
div.ab: Because they were ashamed to declare their desire, because they were wanting to be with her.
div.note: Swete and Ziegler use ἀναγγεῖλαι instead. The meaning is pretty much the same, except the απο ‘from’ usually implies conveying a message from someone else, but, according to Strong’s Lexicon, it can also be used for a declaration of truth. https://biblehub.com/greek/518.htm
div.ab: And they were closely watching eagerly day by day.
They said to one another, Let us go into home now because of lunch time. And having gone out they separated from one another.
And having returned they came to the same (place) and querying one another the reason they confessed their desire. And then they arranged time in common when they will be able to find her alone.

And it came to pass, as they were observing for an opportune day, she entered once, just as yesterday and the third day with two maidens alone, and she desired to bathe in the garden because it was burning hot.
And there was not anyone there, except the two elders having been hidden and watching her.
div.note: κεκρυμμένοι a perfect participle suggests a state which was a result of something already done but the present participle παρατηροῦντες shows ongoing action…they are hidden, and remain hidden but they are actively watching because παρατηροῦντες is in the present.
div.ab: And she said to her maidens, Bring me oil and soap, and close the doors of the garden so that I may bathe.
And they did as she said and they closed the doors of the garden and went out through the side doors to bring the things commanded to them, and they did not see the elders, because they were hidden.
And it happened when the maidens went out, and the two elders rose up and ran upon her.
div.note: ἐπιτρέχω (which ἐπέδραμον comes from) can imply a hostile action such as running at someone with ill intent, to run upon or at for the purpose of attack or overrun, like an army: See https://lsj.gr/wiki/ἐπιτρέχω.
div.ab: And they said, look! The doors of the garden have been shut and no one sees us and we are in desire of you therefore consent to us and be with us.
div.note: The verbs συγκατάθου and γενοῦ are in the imperative. The two elders are not asking but commanding. They could have said something like συγκαταθήσῃ ἡμῖν καὶ γενήσῃ μεθ' ἡμῶν, ‘will you consent to us and be with us’ in the future middle passive instead of the demanding aorist middle imperative.
div.ab: But if not we will testify against you that a young man was with you and you sent the maidens away from you on account of this.
And Susanna groaned and said I am confined on every side For if I do this it is death for me and if I do not I will not escape your hands.
It is preferable for me to fall into your hands by not taking part than to sin before the Lord.
And Susanna shouted out with a loud voice but the two old men opposite her also shouted.
And one ran and opened the doors of the orchard.
But when they heard the shouting in the orchard those from the house burst in through the side doors to see what had happened with her.
But when the old men said their words the servants were very ashamed because such a word as this had never been said about Susanna.
And it happened on the next day as the people assembled around her husband Jehoiakim the two old men came full of lawless thoughts against Susanna to put her to death. And they said before the people
Send in Susanna daughter of Hilkiah who is the wife of Jehoiakim. Then they sent for her.
And she came and her parents and her children and all her relatives.
But Susanna was very delicate and beautiful in shape.
Then the lawless ones ordered her to be uncovered for she was veiled so that they could be filled with her beauty.
Then those who were with her and all the ones who looked at her began crying.
The two old men arose in the midst of the people and put their hands
on her head.
She wept and looked up into heaven because her heart had trusted in the Lord.
The old men said While we were walking alone in the orchard she entered with two girls and closed the doors of the orchard and sent the girls away.
A young man who was hidden came to her and he lay down with her.
But because we were in the corner of the orchard upon seeing the lawlessness we ran to them.
And when we saw them having sexual intercourse we could not gain possession of that man because he was stronger than us and he opened the doors and leapt away.
But we seized this woman and asked her who the young man was.
And she did not want to tell us. We testify to these things. The assembly believed them as they were elders of the people and judges and they condemned her to die.
But Susanna shouted out with a loud voice and said God Eternal who divines the hidden things who knows everything before their beginning
you realize that they have testified against me with lies.
And look I will die doing nothing wrong that these men maliciously accuse against me.
And the Lord listened to her voice.
And while she was being led away to be put to death God roused the holy spirit of a young boy named Daniel
he cried out with a loud voice I am innocent of the blood of this woman
Then all the people turned toward him and said What is this word that you have spoken?
As he stood in their midst he said In this way you are stupid O people of Israel Without examining or recognizing what is clear you have condemned a daughter of Israel
Go back into the court for these men have testified lies against her.
All the people returned quickly and the elders said to him Come sit in our midst and tell us because God has given you the privilege of an elder.
So Daniel said to them Separate them far from one another and I will question them.
Then when they were separated the one from the other one he called one of them and said to him O you who have become old of evil days now your sins are present which you continued to do before
by judging unrighteous cases and condemning the innocent but dismissing the blameworthy while the Lord says You shall not kill an innocent and righteous person.
Now therefore if you really saw this woman tell us Under what tree did you see them having sexual intercourse with one another He said Under the mastic tree.
Then Daniel said Rightly you have lied against your own headfor the angel of God has already received the statement from God he will split you in half.
After he had removed him he ordered to bring the other and said to him Seed of Canaan and not of Judah beauty has deceived you and lust has distorted your heart.
You used to act in this way to the daughters of Israel and those women since they were frightened would have sexual intercourse with you but a daughter of Judah did not tolerate your lawlessness.
Now therefore tell me Under what tree did you seize them talking to one another So he said Under the evergreen oak.
Daniel said to him Surely you also have lied against your own head for the angel of God is waiting holding a sword to cut you in half to destroy you.
And all the assembly cried out with a loud voice
and praised the God who delivers those who hope in him.

And they stood up against the two old men because Daniel had shown them from their own mouths they were false witnesses. And they did to them just as they had maliciously intended against the neighbor
by acting according to the law of Moses and they killed them. And innocent blood was saved on that day.
Hilkiah and his wife praised for their daughter with Jehoiakim her husband and all their kindred because no unseemly action was found in her.
Daniel became great before the people from day that and beyond.
